title: Welcome to the Deep 7 Research Track Portal
text:
a formal process that allows NOAA scientists the opportunity to dive deeper into our scientific approaches and improve how we assess and manage our fisheries.




not limited by strict management deadlines.




a collaborative process with fishers, state scientists, and federal scientists.






The Deep 7 Research Track is





The research track is made up of several different research modules.
There are many avenues of research we want to explore over the next few years to improve the Deep 7 assessment. Many of the priorities have come directly from suggestions from fishers. Some of our top priorities currently include:





Refining non-commercial catch estimates using fisher numbers, commercial reports, and surveys.




Expanding biosampling by partnering with fishers to collect life history and length data.




Enhancing the BFISH survey by reevaluating fishing methods and sampling grid allocations.




Reassessing the Deep 7 Stock complex and investigating alternative groupings.




And more!














Meet the team behind the work
The members of the Island Fisheries Stock Assessment Program at the Pacific Island Fisheries Science Center are working on the modules for the research track.




John Syslo is the lead assessment scientist for the Deep 7 Bottomfish. He is leading the Research Track and working on a simulation model to understand the trade-offs of assessing the 7 species as complex.















Megumi Oshima is working on a simulation model to test the impact of survey effort on estimating the Opakapaka population.















Hongguang Ma works with the HMRFS data to calculate non-commercial catch for Hawaii stocks.















Marc Nadon is working on alternative approaches for estimating non-commercial catch.















Felipe Carvalho is the branch chief of the Assessment and Research Branch at PIFSC.













How can I get involved?





We will be hosting regular meetings to share our progress and get your input.




If you want to catch up on what happened at previous meetings, click here.




We would love to hear from you, reach out to us at (insert email or some contact method here).
